Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2008 04:31PM runalot08 wrote: Leaf, Sorry to post again but if they offered you an MRI would you do it or are you happy with the Mammo?
Posts.Title: BSE after wire guided excision biopsy shap runalot08

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2008 04:30PM runalot08 wrote: Thank you Leaf, I think that the MRI is probably considered on a case by case basis then.  I heard that they had to be done  at about 7-10 days after start of menses.  I asked my doc so we could time it right and she said that is for women that have problems with cysts and other such benign problems because they are increased in size, number, and such at certain points of the month.  I guess because I have none of these it does not matter.  I think that the scar tissue may be a problem but in my case I think the benefit must out way the risk.  We still have no answers on my breast issue and I think that the MRI will hopefully answer those.  Thanks for your response. Runalot Vickie
Posts.Title: BSE after wire guided excision biopsy shap runalot08

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 02:39PM runalot08 wrote: It is possible for it to be just scar tissue especially if it is right where your first excision or biopsy was. I have a lot of scar tissue that made my MRI light up but they said it was good.  They were only looking for cancer and saw none.  Depending on how you personally scar up it is possible for your scar to connect to other tissues and feel/get bigger.  I scar very well so most of my scars do not have huge lumps under them but I have known people who do just that.  They get more scarring under the skin than on top.  Kind of like a scab inside but of scar tissue.  I think that most radiologists can tell the difference and that is why your screening might be clean.  They found no cancer and that is what they are supposed to look for. They may mention scar tissue or they may not because that is considered benign and usually they do not note it....at least that is how it has worked in my case.  I would relax unless your gut says otherwise then there is no harm asking questions and digging further it is your body.  If you have already had DCIS I understand and am sure you are nervous so it might be good to see someone to relieve your stress.  Vickie
Posts.Title: Lump...Scar Tissue? Shirl runalot08

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2008 04:15AM runalot08 wrote: Leaf, I saw that you posted you had too much scar tissue to do a MRI.  Why is that.  Does it make it harder to see?  Or does it not work as well? I am curious because I know I have scar tissue from implants etc. and am being scheduled to have a MRI. Shap, As I mentioned above I have scar tissue and I do BSE's.  Eventually you will learn what your scars feel like underneath.  You can start now in feeling around getting used to it.  Some docs suggest you massage your scars/incision, once they are closed, so that they will not be as hard.   Just like your breasts before your biopsy with regular BSE's you will get to know them and notice any change.  Hope this helps, Runalot
Posts.Title: BSE after wire guided excision biopsy shap runalot08

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2009 03:18PM runalot08 wrote: Angel, I am glad to see that they got you in for your MRI.  It is wonderful that they did not see any cancer in your MRI.  However, I know how you feel as that there is still something wrong.  The MRI helps but does not really solve your predicament.  With or with out good results there is the matter that something is going on and needs to be dealt with and get taken care of.  I am glad you are pushing to get a biopsy.  Sorry I have not posted to you earlier as I really like to follow how you are doing.  We have done a couple of family days and forgot about the computer.  Here in Japan it is Cherry blossom time.  They have festivals and such.  Do you like flowers?  I only ask because it is stereotypical to assume all of us women like flowers.  I like them on their host plants not as much on my counter cut up.  My preference are spring flowers.   Sorry back to the biopsy.  I have read on here that women have gone to a Derm. for theirs instead of a surgeon.  Either way you are in the right direction.  Ruling out IBC is a huge relief.  I hope this Dr. can get you in and agrees on a Bx for you.  Think about which place or places are worst on your breast/s and where you think that the Dr. should bx.  They may agree with you or even do more than one place.  My Dr. did not really do where I was wanting to but I agreed to it because I felt bad arguing with her in person but she did a very good job.  She took a moon shape from around my aerola that had light skin and dark skin.  She said she's not fond of punch biopsies so that was her preference.   I think the norm is a punch or core bx.  I had a core in 2005 that was just fine.  The next day I could not even tell that I had it done...pain wise that is.  Keep us up on how you are doing and when you have your next appts. Vickie

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2009 03:41PM runalot08 wrote: Angel,  They are moving you now!  Good for that last doc...someone in your corner hopfully.  I am sorry about your blood levels but at least they have found them and can sersue something...now they know something is wrong on some level.  What kind of biopsy are they going to do tomorrow? Lets see...I think today would be a great day for an old movie marathon to keep you mind on something else.  Pick some movies you loved but have not seen for a while and gather a blanket.  Be lazy and cry if they are sad movies, laugh if they are funny.  For me it would be probably a Molly R movie set like Breakfast club,Pretty in Pink, Sixteen Candles...Julia Roberts in Pretty Woman, Runaway Bride etc.   I also like movies with action like Laura Croft Tomb Raider and such.  Never figured I would feel old thinking of my favorite movies.  Oh, I love Grease.  I do not like all the songs but love the movie. Are you still getting dip and dots snow in the area?  There should be something to you on it's way soon :) Vickie
Posts.Title: New info.... angeltam PS73

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2009 04:00PM runalot08 wrote: Angel, I also had a nodule on the underside of the nipple at about 6 o'ckock....that could be felt but not "seen".  This was in September the 1st biopsy of the year ;)  Doc could feel it and said that since he could he could go in and get it.  He did and it came back b9.  I do not know why some show up and some do not.  It could be the density of the breast, the composition of the mass or nodule, or maybe it could be the location of it is in a inherently bad place to be seen?  If the doc is offering I would go for the biopsy or removal of what ever it is.  At the very least you will get some sort of pathology out of it.  Good or bad it will lead you/docs in a direction.  I think this is what you've been wanting...to find something out...it may be the only way.  I will hold your hand while they do it Let us know, P.s. I get my stitches out today!!!  Yayyyyyy they itch something terrible.  I usually "accidentally" pull them out my self but I have been a very good girl.  Vickie
Posts.Title: New info.... angeltam PS73

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2009 05:13PM runalot08 wrote: Angel, I am hoping Monday they will call you with a date for this week.  My fingers are crossed!  Thanks for the blurb.  Yes, In June it will be a year since my story started so as we are all testament it takes different times and procedures to figure out some breast problems whether cancer or B9.  I think there are more than we know out there that have had to do some waiting.  I think it may actually be rare to have the whole process in a couple weeks.  I have heard of those amazing ones too.  Really it comes down to the symptoms, docs, and insurance.  If you have obvious symptoms it is probably much quicker.  As we know insurance makes a huge difference also. Bottom line is that we all need answers what ever our condition and it should'nt take a year..even multiple months.  However, what should happen and what does are two different things.  When it is not obvious what the problem is unfortunately its going to take a while. Angel, I saw the doc for follow up and of course she said it could take a couple of months for us to realize whether the implant removal solves the problem of the pain and thickening/roping.  I figured as much.  She did put in and I have a mammo scheduled for end of May.  I asked about the US because I usually get one every year with the mammo because the girls are so dense and she said that they do not do screening US here.  I said what?  She said unless the rad here sees something needing to be second checked.  The rads here are in my opinion not the best.  So I am wondering what makes them so much better here that they do not need to follow the standard  back in the states. I guess they can see amazingly through the snowstorm that others can not.  I will get one one way or another though  It is my right to full care. Vickie
Posts.Title: New info.... angeltam PS73

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 11:54PM runalot08 wrote: Worried-Husband, How sweet you are for all your worries about your wife.  My Dad was in the same spot you were/are when my mom was learning she had cancer.  My Hubby has been in the same spot with me (5 times)  not cancer though.  I have had 3 of those biopsies come back with sever or chronic inflamation.  No reason for it to show up it just did.  We have never figured out why.  I just want to put your mind to ease with the breast feeding and our health as a women doing it.  Our bodies are made to do it.  Really there is no other reason physically for women to have breasts...aside from the societal norm that breasts seem to equal woman.  Having a child does change the structure inside and out of the breast.  Whether one breast feeds or not she will become engorged and her milk will come in.  (Most women)  Problems can arise from breast feeding but it is like riding a bike..anything can happen you could fall off and break your arm.   Then bike riding would'nt be so good for us.  There are flukes that happen and problems that arise with breast feeding but I think that it's normally just like riding a bike you do not always hurt. Congratulations on the new baby!  I am glad that everything has worked out as it can be scary. You are a good guy for looking out and asking questions for your wife. Vickie
Posts.Title: Core Biopsy - some advice worried_husband NeoPat

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 05:36PM runalot08 wrote: Tricky breasts do not necessarily mean a bad thing.  It just means that they may be more work to make sure they are healthy.  It may mean that they really do not present things as well as other womans breasts.  For example,  some womens breasts are less dense and a radiologist can see things much better they may have no other things like fibrocystic or calcs to present questions.  Others that have tricky breasts are those that have presented problems or are harder to read.  Mine are dense. I am 33. The last last pea size lump I felt and had removed was neither seen by the mammo or the US but could be felt by the doc and myself.  But...the mammo did pick up calcifications that are being watched.  Me I have already had biopsies and problems with mine.  I will always do my mammo's till they come out with something better that is offered to anyone.  I have never heard of the thermal till I came to this site.  It may be great but as I read above if it does not find smaller things it could be leaving women in a situation where they find out to late.  Bottom line I think someone else mentioned is that all testing is not perfect it is how it is used in conjunction with eachother and the person who reads/performs them.
Posts.Title: Mammograms safe or not?? luvz2bmama cp418

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2009 05:33PM runalot08 wrote: As far as I know when I talked to the case manager it was one person.  He was supossed to be the best.  We are trying to rule out breast cancer then follow up on the theory that the doc has about my breast implants having capsular constriction (just left side).  Implants always form a capsule of scartissue around them but sometimes it gets very bad and gets tight with major tissue surrounding it.  That is what my doctors next idea is as to what is causing the breast problems.  The MRI was stated as being good birads of 1.  However, there were things not mentioned like scar tisssue that would most obviously be there.  It seems to me that if it was the capsule with increased amounts of tissue then it would have been stated.  (something like unusually increased amounts of tissue around left breast.)  Usually they state everything they see right.  I have the report and a copy of all the pictures.  Just not sure what to do.  I see doc on Wed two more days. It is the first time since the MRI and I am not sure what she will want to do next.  The only thing I can think of is to have her call or e-mail the radiologist and see if he will look again and if there is gross amounts of scartissue and he just did not note it because it is not cancer related.  However, I think that any kind of thickening is suppossed to be on those reports though? What to do?  I want to close the door on cancer but my gut wont let me stop yet.  I have enlarged not huge nodes under my arm and some just slightly enlarged in the clavical area on that side that were not there prior. They do not really get worried abut them here till they reach 1.5 cm (thier criteria) mine was last measured at 1.43cm  like I said not big but not normal either.  I always thought that my breast pain swelling and shooting to the armpit was from the breast and maybe causing the swollen node could it be the other way around?  Could something be wrong with the node and it is causing the breast problems? (MY wonderful Hubby presented that Q)  OMG if not to make things worse the pea size lump I wrote about having excised in September has grown back.  It is under my aerola and a very hard bb feel to it.  The doc when he took it out said he could not get all of it as we were not in the er but a steralized room for local procedures.  He did not want t risk infection by going any deeper.  (the tissue he removed was mild chronic lobular inflamation is what the path said.   Which is good I guess I am no pathologist...no BC.  But it is back in most likley the same spot and about the same size now.  It has taken about two months for it to get this size each time.  Oh well I just wanted to know if anyone out there has had thier MRI reread by a different facillity and how to go about it if you did. Vickie
Posts.Title: Advice on second opinion/read of MRI runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2008 02:31AM runalot08 wrote: Thank you Traveler.  I just called the Dr. office and they said my path report is in.  The Dr was not available so he has to call me back.  The front desk lady said he will go over it at my appointment but that is not for a whole week!  It is totally wrong for me to sit a week knowing that the reports are in so hopefully he calls me soon.  They can at least say the good news over the phone:) (positive thoughts)  Oh well, we will know soon enough.  Thanks all.  Keep your fingers crossed. runalot08
Posts.Title: Waiting again runalot08 CAZ

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2008 02:18PM runalot08 wrote: I see the controversy over the mammo's and I just think about my Aunt.  She had her first mammo at age 40 on her birthday and that day they found what they thought was cancer...turned out a couple days later they were right.  It was invasive and big (do not remember the specifics)  She ended up with a mast. and very strong rounds of chemo.  My mom at 41 for her 2nd mammo found out she had DCIS.  Neither one of these ladies had near enough radiation in just a couple of mammos to cause cancer.  (My grandma and Great Grandma had cx also) I have seen others on this board that did not have many either.  I do not discount the fact that there is radiation received when doing the mammo but we get radiation from so many other things.  As for cancer in upper income communities I think it would be an interesting study.  I am not a sociologist; however, my thought is that upper income can afford them and the insurance is probably more willing to cover earlier ones for those with family history.  Plus they are more likly to go to the doctor when they are covered even for just a little lump in the breast. Thus finding more early cancers rising the cancer #'s.  The lower income people may receive less benefits or are not willing to pay for the procedure to find out.  Even if there is a symptom they may find it hard to pay the doc when all their money is going to put food on the table.  Thus less cancer reported... not necessarily less cancers.  They may be walking around with it because they did not get the mammo or can't afford it.  I have seen a few people writing and upset because they desperately wanted breast help and could not get some one to help them because they did not have insurance or money.  These ladies look up and call place after place.  Really it is to each thier own on whether or not one worries about mammo radiation.  I am not going to stay out of the sun as I live on an island.  I am not going to stop eating meat because of the hormones.  (I like meat and I think the protien is worth it)  There are so many things that can and I am sure do harm us.  Just weigh your priorities and beliefs.  If you do not want the mammo then do not get it.  If you do then do it.  I do it because I can and while I do it I remember those that can't. Runalot
Posts.Title: Mammograms safe or not?? luvz2bmama cp418

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2008 08:26PM runalot08 wrote: Misawa47, Sounds like you are military or associated with the military?  I am also.  I am down here in Okinawa and as far as I know if you are either military or dependent they should cover any medical you need unless it is elective.  I am sorry you are having to pay yourself.  Depending on your situation you should'nt have to.  I am probably going to be visiting Hawaii very soon myself.  I have a situation with my breast that we feared at first was IBC but the biopsy performed here came back negative.  Now they are thinking it could be something having to do with my implants.  I have had them for almost 4 years and no trouble till now.  The doc is thinking that the implant is somehow hitting or rubbing on nerves.  My left breast is swollen and very painful sometimes stabbing pain,  I have a red rash that comes and goes, my nodes under my arm are swollen etc.  They do no MRI's here so I cant have one of those.  As far as I know Tricare will be paying for me to go where ever I have to if they can not treat me here.  If you are not military will your insurance not cover your expenses?  It is not exactly elective for you to have a biopsy :) They do biopsies down here at Lester.  I hope all goes well with your biopsy and will think good thoughts for you.  Where at in Hawaii are you getting your medical?  I know that there is a military hospital and a civilian one.  I think that my doc said I would go to the civilian one because the military one is very busy.  If you don't mind could you PM me and let me know how the facilities and staff are.  Which ones you recommend or to stay away from.  If you could that would be very nice.  Timtam or Fumi, Ohio gosaimas.  It is wonderful of you to give the information for your local area hospitals and clinics.  I was thinking of just flying to Seattle and dropping into a clinic before I found a doc that would listen to me.  It is nice to know that there are other places that are closer.  I have family that I will have to leave here if I have to go to the States.  It is cheaper to fly them to main land then all the way.  Do you know of any facilities on Okinawa?  Does your doctor know anything about IBC or has he treated anyone with it?  It is misdiagnosed so often and I really am nervous in my gut that just because the biopsy came back negative that it still might be.  (the biopsies often come back neg if the right spot is not hit)  The fact that there are no MRI's here for the breast really bothers me.  It seems to be the best test available.  I do not want to wait till there are more symptoms because that means the disease is then further along.  Sorry I am rambling this board seems to be my only place to vent or tell my worries.  Anyway, I think it is really great that you are able to help with information on your local area.  I think there should be a thread where people post if they are in a different country/state and have knowledge about the local cancer facilities.  That way people traveling and of course the military or those who live abroad can easily find info for places in their area to go to if they have a problem. Thanks again, Runalot08
Posts.Title: Follow Up bikkuri Misawa47

Posts.Content: runalot08 wrote: I have posted in other threads since Sept.  I am considering a bilateral profelactic mast.  I have not been diagnosed but have had 5 biopsies in less than or just about 4 years.  I also have significant family history including Mom and Aunt.  I have had the BRAC testing and came up with a variant on Brac 2.  No one else in my family has had testing so it does tell me everything.  I know I do not have any of the major variants they are looking for...but do the others in my family either?  The genetic counselor said it would tell us more if others in my family were tested but that is not going to happen.  Majority of family members with breast cancer in my family were from age 40 - 50.  I think all but one pre-menopausal.  Is there anyone else out there that is/has considered this step even before diagnosis.  I am wondering about any feelings good /bad, and how it was done.  Any and all advice or experience would be great.  I want to know about all ramifications good or bad that I could run into.  Thank you ahead of time. Vickie Only those who are strong enough are chosen to receive the greatest of challenges. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bi-lateral prof mast? runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2009 05:31PM runalot08 wrote: Ladies, Thank you for all the recent info. Debbie I hope your surgery went well.  I am sure you wont be on line for a while but I am thinking about you.  My fight for a bilateral prof mast was denied.  I guess my Mom having BC at 41 and my aunt at 40. Then there are my great aunts (3 of them), Great grandmas etc was not enough.  I have a variant but it is not considered to be important.  I hope that others who want to get past the constant chaos have better luck.  So right now I am on my second round of antibiotics for swollen nodes in the armpit neck and clavicle.  (but no technology can see anything wrong with my breasts) What a mess.  I know that some women feel a loss when they have the mastectomy and I am not naive and saying I wouldn't but it would be a relief.  Debbie let us know how it went and how you feel when you are well enough.  Vickie Runalot
Posts.Title: Bi-lateral prof mast? runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 09:46AM runalot08 wrote: Smirks  Thank you for your insight.  I think I am understanding what you are saying about your flap now.  I am hoping if this is a possibility that I can elect what I would like to have.  I think I would have the skin and nipple sparing if possible.  I am still looking everything up and reviewing what I know.  It is in others hands at the moment.  I think it will take a couple of weeks before I get any idea of what my coverage will do for me payment wise. Leslie  I am sorry about your mom I know it was many years ago but if she died of BC then each time you go through a biopsy/lumpectomy I am sure it brings back some pain.  Why do you feel you are a worrier.  Isn't that what we all do about this stuff.  I think everyone I know who has been effected by the disease worries about it.  It reminds us that we are not immortal.  I think that the worrying works both ways.  It can make you really appreciate the things usually looked over.  It is stress...period.  I look at it this way... each time I have a lumpectomy I am out of the loop on my life.  The first week is all about the waiting/ stress.  Then depending on how big the lump was your daily exercise routine is out the window.  I run, so each time I get cut I am out for two weeks minimum.  Docs do not want stitches to bust.  Plus it can make the scar worse.  I am very tired of the hold button being pushed on my life.  If it was every once in a while maybe every five years a scare o.k. I can really deal with that but it has been constant for about 4 years.  In between the surgeries are the extra ultra sounds, mammos, and Dr. check ups.  It is just getting old for me.  That is why I am considering getting rid of the girls.  I am done with children so I do not need them for breast feeding.  Really they are just accessories...they are required to be there (lovely and plump) by society they are not a medical necessity.  I am not sure what I will think when it actually comes down to the decision day but those are my thought for now.  Just rambling on to let you know it is o.k./ normal to worry about it.  I am sure you and I are not the only ones  Vickie
Posts.Title: Bi-lateral prof mast? runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 05:48PM runalot08 wrote: Mudt, Thank you.  I have brought up the testing to my mother several times (actually acouple of days ago was the last) with the hint that it would really help out but she is not interested.  My Aunt is old fashioned in the same way.  They just want it to stay behind them.  The rest of the women with BC have all passed away. I did not think of the tumor testing.  Would they have to o.k. that personally?  I think that the GC if she wanted would be able to move on that?  You are right I would not worry nearly as much if I knew either of them had the gene and I do not. No...I am bummed...I did  not get to do the run.  I had my excisional bx a couple of weeks before it.  The Dr. said no running for two weeks and by then I was not in the same shape.  I know you do not lose muscle all that fast but I think it was mental also.  I am trying to get another half in this February.  I really started back up about 2-3 weeks ago and then fell out of the tree (last week) trying to get an airplane for my son.  (I got it ) So I bruised my heel and some of the tendons around the ankle.  I am going to try back today I think.  I am doing between 3-4 miles with no problem and this week was going to up it to 5-6.  We will see.  I am in the mind frame that two halfs make a whole...right?  I will do the marathon it might just have to be another year. Thanks for your insight and remembering about the run, Vickie

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2009 04:51AM runalot08 wrote: Hi Annie thanks for all your thoughts.  The more info I get the better I feel that when I go to make a decision I will not wonder if I knew enough.  I am just waiting to see what the Genetic counselor has to say.  All of my info was put together and sent to her last week.  It will take her a while I guess to let us know what she thinks and if my insurance will pay for it.  I think a couple of weeks? I talked to a friend today who's cousin had it done.  She was BRAC + and her siblings died in their late 20's early 30's.  She did not have cancer yet and was determined to live longer and with out the high stress.  The mast is not 100% but it is so much better on the mind.  For her there have been no regrets and she never looked back. Mutd, I can honestly say I am not sure why they do not get it.  I can not pressure them any more though because it is their choice.  They may feel better or less pressure not knowing.  I can understand it in a way.  It does not help me but I understand. Vickie

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 08:42PM runalot08 wrote: Thank you ladies for all your stories and advice.  I am still waiting to hear what I will get offered.  My hubby is warming up to the idea.  He, in the beginning, thought I was taking to drastic a measure but has realized that I am doing my research and plan to make an informed decision.  I think his worry was that I was being hasty about it.  Stonebrook you said that you had bilat with immediate implants.  Did they do a skin and nipple sparing?  Or did they use a different method?  The skin sparing was what I am hoping to be offered since I have not actually been diagnosed...I feel the "yet" in my gut.  What do you do for check ups.  Do they MRI you once a year or US?  I am sure they still keep tabs on those that get mastectomies...right? Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2009 08:33PM runalot08 wrote: No, I am not in the States...unfortunately.  I am associated with the military so I am in Okinawa for another 1.5 yrs or so.  I was not denied by insurance...it did not even get that far.  My paperwork and history was sent to Hawaii to a counselor there and she deemed it unnecessary and said basically no before it got to anyone else.  When I was in the states 5 years ago another military doc offered it to me after my genetic testing.  I said that I would keep it in mind...that was 5 biopsies ago.  Guess I have to wait till I get back and I may have more room to fight it.  My Aunt (age at Diag...40) is doing the genetic testing and has already had her blood drawn.  That should help us out.  My mother had cancer also BC at age 41.  She is not entertaining the idea of a blood test.  I am so glad to hear that most are happy with their results...having to worry less and not have at least one biopsy a year must be very nice.  One day I will join the club I just have to get out of this area to press my issues.  Vickie

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2009 07:27PM runalot08 wrote: Thank you Springtime. I just have a problem with giving up atleast a couple of months of sanity every year with abnormal stuff.  Even If they do not biopsy it I am in for every 3 months diagnostics.  It starts to wear on the psyche and leave a person wondering if it is this year or this time that a biopsy will come back something other than B9.  Literally for 5 years now I have had something every year.  Lets see...2 aspirations, one core biopsy, 2 excisional lumpectomies, and one skin biopsy where they took a  slice of skin around my aerola down about a half cm...don't really know what that was called.  I got to have an MRI this year also also.(well last year Dec29)  If it is a money issue one would think that just doing the dbl mast would be cheaper than my yearly chaos.  It definitely would be easier on the mind once I got use to the loss of the breasts.  I know that the mast is not fail proof but it does give a great deal more assurance.  I will wait as I am still having breast issues as it is.  However, come 2010 I will be in the old Dr's office requesting the procedure.  I am hoping to do it before we find something because then I may get to keep my own skin and do implants.  If it comes to having to do it because cancer is found I will most likley not have that choice.  With what is in the family they have not been able to keep their breasts because it was invasive and in multiple areas.  I do not have enough skin for either the tram flap or probably the belly one either as I am a runner. I am not super skinny but small enough that it would not be an option.  I have read that you need a bit of excess skin so for sure the tram would not work.  Is that true or can they do those procedures on any one? Oh well thanks for listening (reading) to my long rant. Vickie
Posts.Title: Bi-lateral prof mast? runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: runalot08 wrote: I am interested in how...if anyone...has gotten a second opinion on their MRI?  How did you do it?  Do you just call someplace and say hey can your read my MRI for me or does the doctor have to do all of this?  Will I pay for it?  I am not against paying for it but just really want someone else to read my pictures and say the same thing as the first radiologist.  For closure, I guess.  What I am going through has no rhyme or reason and no answer.  If anyone out there has had a 2nd opinion could you let me know how it was achieved?  Vickie Only those who are strong enough are chosen to receive the greatest of challenges. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Advice on second opinion/read of MRI runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2009 01:30AM runalot08 wrote: Thank you Gg08.  IBC scare is what started this all.  They have come to believe I do not have it but I am kinda done with the whole roller coaster thing.  Was your IBC obvious or a sneaky one?  DId you have reconstruction? Smirks44what happened with the (failed flap)?  Did they also remove your skin on your breast as well as the breast tissue.  (I think that if they leave the skin that is called skin sparing mast?) So for you did they take the skin and all?  I am in beginning research for this and am not even sure it is a option.  The genetic counselor offered it to me four years ago and I said I would think about it.  Now five biopsies later I am considering it and the Genetic counselor at our new base has to go over everything and "approve" it again.  We'll see...my husband thinks it is a radical move but he is not fully in this each time I have a problem or get called back.  He said he would support me either way but it is not his first choice.  I always knew the first time I had anything but normal tissue I was going to do it.  Thank you both, Vickie
Posts.Title: Bi-lateral prof mast? runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 05:52PM runalot08 wrote: Wow what support thank you everyone for your stories and advice.  I really appreciate it all.  I have not heard anything back but as far as I can tell it will probably take a while.  I have to go through all procedures and chain so who knows.  I am waiting on the counselor she has all my info and is going over it.  Thanks again for everything and keep them coming it only makes me stronger with knowledge. Vickie
Posts.Title: Bi-lateral prof mast? runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: runalot08 wrote: I have posted in other threads since Sept.  I am considering a bilateral profelactic mast.  I have not been diagnosed but have had 5 biopsies in less than or just about 4 years.  I also have significant family history including Mom and Aunt.  I have had the BRAC testing and came up with a variant on Brac 2.  No one else in my family has had testing so it does tell me everything.  I know I do not have any of the major variants they are looking for...but do the others in my family either?  The genetic counselor said it would tell us more if others in my family were tested but that is not going to happen.  Majority of family members with breast cancer in my family were from age 40 - 50.  I think all but one pre-menopausal.  Is there anyone else out there that is/has considered this step even before diagnosis.  I am wondering about any feelings good /bad, and how it was done.  Any and all advice or experience would be great.  I want to know about all ramifications good or bad that I could run into.  Thank you ahead of time. Vickie Only those who are strong enough are chosen to receive the greatest of challenges. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Bi-lateral prof mast? runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2009 05:53PM runalot08 wrote: Karen, How long ago did you have yours done?  Did the nipples do alright? I am not sure I would mind losing them if they said not to keep them.  I like having mine but I would eventually get over it I think.  Especially knowing my chances for being diagnosed went down.  I am wanting to do everything I can to get rid of this annual sometimes biannual breast mess.  For 4 years I have taken a beating.  I would like to give my personal risk a beating back.  I want to do all I can to make sure I am here for my family.  Sounds like I am being morbid and thinking that I am going to get cancer and all but when I look at my family history and risk it is to me big. Thank you for being open about your experience.  It really helps to see all the advice from others. Vickie I
Posts.Title: Bi-lateral prof mast? runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: Nov 29, 2008 01:29AM runalot08 wrote: Fumi, Actually the lack of MRI is from the bases.  I am told that I can not have one here because there are no resources here. (Meaning they can not do it on the bases)  I do not know why they won't send us off base to the local establishments if they can not provide the services themselves.  I am very close to finding somewhere to go and pay for it myself.  I am just about at wits end with all of this.  The pain and swelling has been since August.  The docs are really trying to figure out what is going on but because the mammo came back o.k. and the biopsy came back negative they have given up the cancer idea. (I am 33 with very dense breasts so that does not help either)  I just do not think that they see all the posts that come back negative or fine then the patient really has something serious.  If they do not biopsy IBC in the right place it will obviously come back negative. They can not link my problems to anything else really.  Right now the doc is thinking that maybe my implants I have had for 4 years are hitting nerves and causing the pain.  However that does not cause swelling or swollen nodes and an on again off again rash.  They are just pulling ideas out and trying things to see if they work instead of sending me to specialists with the right equipment to rule out IBC.  My breast is swollen and hurts all the time.  They have me on pain meds and even the stabbing pain breaks through that.  My nodes are not huge but they are swollen under my arm and I even felt them for the first time in my abdomen the other day.  My doc said that it was because I was so skinny.  I wish :)  I am 5'4 and 120ish.  I have been smaller and never felt lymph nodes in my pelvis area before. Oh well, thank you so much for the information I may print it out and take it to my next Dr. appt and ask why I can't see one of them.  See what they say. Your great!  Thank you again for all of your help. Runalot- Vickie
Posts.Title: Follow Up bikkuri Misawa47

Posts.Content: Sep 29, 2008 09:49PM runalot08 wrote: Congratulations on B9 results.  That is what they gave me also but am just today going in to find out what the real problem is.  They have not really said anything except that they don't see cancer.  I am happy to see another person come back with good news.  I keep seeing the other news and wish for all it could be different.  I have never heard of a BSGI how is that performed?  I am with the miitary and all we have here is US and Mammo.  They do not even have the tools to do breast MRI.
Posts.Title: BSGI tests frangaydos ajwgis

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2008 01:12PM runalot08 wrote: Just a question to add to my post that I forgot to ask.  Is it normal to have nothing on the mammogram (except density) and nothing onUS but still be able to palpate a mass?  It seems that if it was felt and able to be removed that it should have shown up on one of those tools right?
Posts.Title: Waiting again runalot08 CAZ

Posts.Content: runalot08 wrote: I am new to the form thing but have been reading them for months.  I have decided to get my feet wet.  To start out my mom was diagnosed at 41 with BC but they got it early and she only had to have radiation.  My Aunt (paternal) found out she had cancer for her 40th birthday. Hers was invasive not sure of the stage but she had a mastectomy and over a years worth of diff chemo and other stuff.  Then of course there are great aunts and great grandmas that have had BC/OC. I had a scare in 2005 and had a lumpectomy at age 30 came back B9. Have been doing regular mammo's and US's since. I currently am waiting on results of a I guess you could call it a lumpectomy/biopsy.  In May/June I found a pea size thing you could call a lump under my areola about the 9o'clock position.  It was hard and unmoveable like a pellet gun shot me and it stuck.  It is swollen a bit on top of the areola and has some of the skin around the bottom of the areola doing a bit of tightning.  There is pain sometimes like a heavyness and heat.  I have implants (subpectoral)  They sent me for a mammo and did not see anything on it.  So they did an US and did not see anything either (except for a enlarged node I have had for about two years).  The Dr after I did some prying said that they would take it out because he could feel it even though the other machines did not see it.  Had that done last week and have to wait till next week for my appt/results.  He is pretty sure that it is nothing and should come back clean but of course with my fam hist I am not as casual.  I am out of the country with the military and do not really have options of a second opinion.  The Dr said it did not feel like cancer.  Can you really tell the difference by feeling it?  I was awake when he cut it out and it seemed like he was having a hard time getting it out like it was deep seated in the tissue.  He said he got enough and if it came back as anything other than scar tissue they would go back in.  Is that good like maybe it was not in a duct or such?  I just needed to post and get it off my chest (pun intended:).  My hubby is great be he is not worried like me he I think does not fully understand the stress.  Do some cancers feel like a pellet?  Oh well just wanted to see if there are any others out there with any sage advice.  Thanks Only those who are strong enough are chosen to receive the greatest of challenges. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Waiting again runalot08 CAZ

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2008 01:04PM runalot08 wrote: Leaf, Thank you for your reply.  My girlfriend and I laughed at the Dr. saying that it did not feel like cancer.  I figured it was insane.  Unfortunalty, cysts were not even mentioned when he took it out.  It was solid and firm about the size of a pea.  (I would rather have a cyst:)  I see everyone seems to be getting thier results back in about a week.  Lovely system I am on is two weeks.  Today is one week.  I know that the odds are in my favor but it is still a minkey on my back.  Thanks again it is great to see what others think and have a conversation that dosn't make me feel like I am over exaggerating!
Posts.Title: Waiting again runalot08 CAZ

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2008 11:28PM runalot08 wrote: Thank you both it just seems wierd to feel something and not see it on either of those.  I think that for now I will just do what I can to not obsess about it.  Hopefully it is scar tissue maybe that is why they did not pick it up.  Oh well, it is not like I can do anything about it any way.  How long should a boob stay swollen after a lumpectomy?  My Dr. was awsome and I have just a small incision right at the line of the breast and areola.  I am guessing that is  a sensitive area and it may stay sore and swollen longer.  Thank you for your support even just the hang in theres.  It is a different feeling getting it from this board than the people I interact with real time.  Must be because everyone here has gone throught the stage of waiting and knows how it feels.  Thank you both.
Posts.Title: Waiting again runalot08 CAZ

Posts.Content: Sep 25, 2008 08:58AM runalot08 wrote: I did get the results and no cancer was seen.  I do not have the path reports and I see the doc next Tues.  He said that there was lobular inflamation?  Have any others gotten this?  There has been no trauma or anything.  I guess we will discuss that and work on finding a reason for the pain and swelling on one side then.  I am not sure if they are going to go back in and get the rest of the "inflamation" or leave it.  I really hope that others will get no cancer results to who are waiting.  They say that things happen in threes right. Thanks again!  I will post again next week after talking with the doc
Posts.Title: Waiting again runalot08 CAZ

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2009 09:45PM runalot08 wrote: By Grace, Not to worry you but my Aunt just went through the genetic testing and counseling.  I did years ago.  They told her if there is genetic mutation she has just as much chance getting it from mother or father.  My aunt was told it is even stronger chance coming if it is on the paternal side.  I do not know medically if that is true...I am hoping some one who does know may read this and either correct it or confirm it.  We all pass things on to our children that we wish they did not have to bother with in life.  It is a sad thought but she will learn to manage the situation just as you have.  However, she has a bonus because you are right there with knowledge to help her if she has q's and problems. Vickie

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2009 04:42AM runalot08 wrote: I wish all doctors period took the opportunity to read boards like this.  They may gain a perspective impossible to obtain by merely seeing and diagnosing/ or missing the diagnosis.  They would see how much frustration is built up by their actions/ inactions.  They may see people as human rather than Mrs. 0900. They should read all the threads where people list thier stories and symptoms.  Learn how they are different in most all women and not as text book as they think.  I bet if they did that they would wonder a lot more about the woman who presented with "atypical symptoms".   Oh, and who ever mentioned the receptionist who needs a clue...I am with you!
